title: 106_hr3655
content:
The Act is titled the "Improved Medical Care for Troops and Retirees Act." It includes a Medicare subvention project for military retirees and dependents. The "Improved Medical Care for Troops and Retirees Act" includes amendments to the Social Security Act regarding the Medicare subvention project for military retirees and dependents. Effective January 1, 2001, the limitation on the number of sites for the program is repealed, and the program is to be conducted nationwide by January 1, 2006. The time limitation on the project is eliminated, and caps on the project are no longer applicable after calendar year 2001. The "Improved Medical Care for Troops and Retirees Act" amends the Social Security Act to replace "demonstration project" with "program" throughout. This includes changing the heading and definitions to reflect the shift from project to program. The amendment replaces "demonstration project" with "program" in the Social Security Act, including modifying terms and conditions of the program and assessing costs to the health care program. The amendment to the Social Security Act replaces "demonstration project" with "program" and includes provisions for patient satisfaction and continuation of care. Amendments also involve redesignating paragraphs and changing submission requirements for administering Secretaries. The administering Secretaries cannot terminate benefits for Medicare-eligible military retirees or dependents unless they no longer meet the defined criteria. Payments can be made on a fee-for-service basis for individuals not enrolled in the program as described. The Secretary of Defense shall reimburse military treatment facilities for health care provided under this section, with amendments made to ensure payments are made on a fee-for-service basis. Reimbursement for health care at military treatment facilities will be conducted using the fee-for-service method as described in subsection (l). Various subsections are amended to ensure compliance with enrollment and payment requirements. The amendments made in subsections (F) to (I) ensure compliance with enrollment and payment requirements. The effective date for these changes is January 1, 2001, and applies to services provided on or after that date. Additionally, a restriction on eligibility in Section 1896(b)(1) is eliminated. Elimination of restrictive policy in Section 1896(b)(1) allows participation in the program without restrictions based on primary care manager type for medicare-eligible military retirees and dependents enrolled in TRICARE Prime. The amendment in Section 1896 of the Social Security Act provides Medigap protection for enrollees in the program, ensuring similar enrollment and termination processes as with Medicare+Choice organizations. The amendment in Section 1896 of the Social Security Act adjusts reimbursement rates by removing "95 percent of" in subsection (i)(1). SEC. 3. Extension of FEHBP demonstration program. Section 1108 of title 10, United States Code is amended to extend the enrollment period and deadlines for certain individuals in the program. Section 1108 of title 10, United States Code is amended to extend the enrollment period and deadlines for certain individuals in the program by adjusting the time frames for completion. SEC. 4 amends the National Defense Authorization Act to allow family members of certain duty-assigned members to receive care under the Supplemental Care Program. SEC. 5 expands the pharmacy program. SEC. 5 expands the pharmacy program under the Strom Thurmond National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1999, ensuring equivalent benefits to those provided under the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1993. Authorization of appropriations is set at $455,000,000 for fiscal year 2001 and $485,000,000 for fiscal year 2002. SEC. 6. IMPROVEMENTS UNDER THE TRICARE PROGRAM. Amends section 1095d of title 10, United States Code to eliminate copayments for certain covered beneficiaries under TRICARE Prime. Amends TRICARE program by eliminating non-availability statement requirement and reducing catastrophic cap to $3,000 for covered beneficiaries under TRICARE Standard and TRICARE Extra. SEC. 7. REIMBURSEMENT FOR CERTAIN TRAVEL EXPENSES.

Amends Chapter 55 of title 10, United States Code to provide reimbursement for travel expenses for covered beneficiaries referred to specialty care providers more than 100 miles away from their primary care provider.
